newsitem.title: UK: Naphtha ends higher in invigorated European market.
newsitem.headline: Naphtha ends higher in invigorated European market.

text.p: NWE naphtha prices rallied slightly on Thursday, invigorated by strong crude futures, heavy swaps buying and traders manoeuvring cargoes like chess pieces in the Med.
High freight rates in the Med have led to cargoes being co-loaded with options to send them either to NWE or the U.S.

Cash traders in NWE said some deals were still getting done at a discount to the swaps prices, underlining an amply supplied local market. Boosted by crude's gains the last two days, Feb swaps ended $1.50 higher at $224.50/$225.50 a tonne and March rose $1.75 to $218.75/$219.75.
NWE cargoes normally would be assessed on a notional basis at a premium to the February swaps, near $226/$228 cif.
But one trader confirmed an 8,500 tonne Russian parcel with 70 paraffinic material was sold on Wednesday at a roughly $2 discount to nearby swaps.
"The notional cargo numbers are above the swaps but the physical trade took place below the swaps," he said. "There is no real trade on the big ships (in NWE)."
This trader said a 28,000 tonne Skikda cargo was heading to Tarragona, Spain, for early February loading, and that possibly another cargo was heading there later in the month.
Nova fixed a 57,000 tonne cargo from Skikda that originally was heading for the U.S. but, due to unattractive prices, may end up with an end-user in Antwerp, sources said.
A 55,000 tonne Skikda cargo from Mira also has options for the U.S. and Northwest Europe, and sources said at least one piece of that cargo will end up in NWE.
A high paraffinic piece between 5,000 and 10,000 tonnes was sold earlier Thursday at cif high quotes +$3.25, traders said.
One trader said the arbitrage from NWE to the U.S. was shut and that cheaper propane prices there will make naphtha even more unattractive for cracking.
One source said one trader was a heavy buyer in the swaps the last few days, spawning fears of a tigher market in February that indirectly has lifted physical prices.
